Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the conference "Southeast Analysis Meeting: SEAM 2014" that will be held March 14-15, 2014, on the campus of Clemson University.

This event is the latest in a twenty-nine-year-long series that has hosted conferences covering a wide spectrum of subareas of analysis and that has become the leading venue in the U.S. for function-theoretic operator theory. SEAM 2014 will again span a broad swath of analysis, featuring five plenary speakers who will address topics in operator theory (John McCarthy, Stefan Richter) and harmonic analysis (Ingrid Daubechies, Michael Lacey, Camil Muscalu) in one-hour talks. Three junior speakers (Yen Do, Kate Juschenko, Constanze Liaw) will deliver thirty-minute plenary lectures. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 30th Southeastern Analysis Meeting (SEAM 2014) took place in Clemson, South Carolina on Friday, March 7 and Saturday, March 8, 2014.

SEAM 2014 had 7 plenary lectures:

1. Yen Do (Yale University), Lp theory for Outer Measures

2. Michael Lacey (Georgia Tech), The Two Weight Inequality for the Cauchy Transform for R to C

3. Constanze Liaw (Baylor University), Spectral Analysis of the Exceptional Jacobi Differential Expression for Extreme Parameter Choices

4. John McCarthy (Washington University in St. Louis), Non-commutative Function Theory

5. Camil Muscalu (Cornell University), Higher Singular Integrals

6. Natasha Pavlovic (University of Texas), Unconditional Uniqueness for the Cubic Gross-Pitaevskii Hierarchy via Quantum de Finetti

7. Stefan Richter (University of Tennessee), Graph Transformations of the Bergman Shift

Two of the plenary speakers were junior mathematicians and two were female. In addition there were 37 parallel-session talks (mostly by graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty members, includinga number of women), each in a half-hour slot, with at most three talks in parallel simultaneously. Topics covered included the SEAM traditional function-theoreticoperator theory (e.g. functional calculus for operators and operator-tuples,including non-commutative functional calculus; Toeplitz, Hankel, weighted-shift,and composition operators as well as harmonic analysis on various kinds of analyticfunction spaces, sometimes in several variables; the corona problem in varioussettings; noncommutative function algebras), but also some talks touching on more applied topics (sampling, multiresolution analysis, and wavelets) as well as sometalks on topics from partial differential equations (completely integrable PDEsand Navier-Stokes equation).

The topics of the plenary lectures reflected the major current developments in the area of mathematical analysis.  The intimate format of the meeting fostered collaborations between younger and more senior mathematicians.

SEAM 30 successfully continued the tradition of serving as the first significant research conference for many beginning researchers and advanced graduate students. Out of the 79 registered participants, 32 were graduate students. 

NSF funding was used primarily for participant support. Priority was given to graduate students, post-docs, junior faculty, and members of underrepresented groups. The total number of participants funded was 42 ($20,638.23), including 23 graduate students ($10,424.39), 16 junior mathematicians ($8,177.94), and 8 female mathematicians ($4,059.26). 


Last Modified: 01/31/2015
Modified by: Mishko Mitkovski
